articles.headline: U.S. Proposes Ban on ‘Flash’ Trading on Wall Street
articles.snippet: In addition to banning flash orders, regulators are also seeking new limits on the credit rating industry.
articles.abstract: In addition to banning flash orders, regulators are also seeking new limits on the credit rating industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is an obscure art of Wall Street, a technique that gives a scattering of traders an edge over everyone else  and the Securities and Exchange Commission wants to stamp it out.

articles.headline: The Go-Go Years, Revisited
articles.snippet: A family of funds uses a kind of arbitrary pricing that the S.E.C. threw out in the 1960s.
articles.abstract: A family of funds uses a kind of arbitrary pricing that the S.E.C. threw out in the 1960s.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been four decades since the go-go years of the late 1960s, when hot mutual funds captured the imagination of investors by reporting performance that was too good to be true.

articles.headline: Medical Editors Push for Ghostwriting Crackdown
articles.snippet: Medical journals are being pressed to adopt tougher disclosure policies on industry-financed research.
articles.abstract: Medical journals are being pressed to adopt tougher disclosure policies on industry-financed research.
articles.lead_paragraph: The scientific integrity of medical research has been clouded in recent years by articles that were drafted by drug company-sponsored ghostwriters and then passed off as the work of independent academic authors.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: 4 Firms Agree to Settlement in New York Pension Fund Inquiry
articles.snippet: Four investment firms agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle an investigation by New York’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, into the state’s pension fund, Mr. Cuomo said Thursday.
articles.abstract: Four investment firms agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle an investigation by New York’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, into the state’s pension fund, Mr. Cuomo said Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four investment firms agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle an investigation by New York’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, into the state’s pension fund, Mr. Cuomo said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Health Ills Abound as Farm Runoff Fouls Wells
articles.snippet: Farm waste, the biggest polluter of American rivers, is largely unregulated by many of the laws designed to prevent pollution and protect drinking water.
articles.abstract: Farm waste, the biggest polluter of American rivers, is largely unregulated by many of the laws designed to prevent pollution and protect drinking water.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORRISON, Wis.  All it took was an early thaw for the drinking water here to become unsafe.

articles.headline: New Missile Shield Strategy Scales Back Reagan’s Vision
articles.snippet: While President Obama’s missile defense plan relies on scaled-back technology, it remains, like Ronald Reagan’s vision of a Star Wars system, grounded in international politics.
articles.abstract: While President Obama’s missile defense plan relies on scaled-back technology, it remains, like Ronald Reagan’s vision of a Star Wars system, grounded in international politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The new plan that President Obama laid out for a missile shield against Iran on Thursday turns Ronald Reagan’s vision of a Star Wars system on its head: Rather than focusing first on protecting the continental United States, it shifts the immediate effort to defending Europe and the Middle East.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Google Aims to Wrest Display Ads From Yahoo
articles.snippet: The company will introduce a long-awaited system that will instantly match ad buyers with ad sellers when a customer visits a Web site.
articles.abstract: The company will introduce a long-awaited system that will instantly match ad buyers with ad sellers when a customer visits a Web site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Google is pushing for a second act.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Despite Warning, Thousands Rally in Iran
articles.snippet: The opposition protests were the largest in two months and came on an annual day of support for Palestinians.
articles.abstract: The opposition protests were the largest in two months and came on an annual day of support for Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Tens of thousands of protesters chanted and carried banners through the heart of Tehran and other Iranian cities on Friday, hijacking a government-organized anti-Israel march and injecting new life into the country’s opposition movement.

articles.headline: Fed Considers Sweeping Rules on Bank Pay
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s rules, which would reportedly apply not just to executives, would scrutinize the structure of compensation in an effort to discourage excessive risk-taking.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s rules, which would reportedly apply not just to executives, would scrutinize the structure of compensation in an effort to discourage excessive risk-taking.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve and the Treasury are preparing broad new rules that would force banks to rein in practices that made multimillionaires out of many financial executives during the housing bubble, officials said.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Louise Story
